comment_text: If we are looking at the same study, the observations were made of soda treatment for gill injuries in fish. However, many bass fisherman use the technique for gullet-hooked fish that bleed from their injury, not gill injuries which are FAR more lethal. The soda is poured into the fish's mouth and not "on them". It seems to work. The fish are kept in a live well to verify their survival before release. Consider the possibility that slowing the blood flow, even if only temporarily, provides an opportunity for the blood to naturally coagulate at the wound site, preventing the fish from bleeding out.

No, this is not a real fishing thing.  There are no references to it prior to ~2015 when suddenly every crappy blog on the internet published a story along the lines of "Hey you wacky fishermen, stop pouring soda on fish!"  Doing a Google search for "pour soda on a bleeding fish" and restricting the date range to 2000 - 2005 gives no meaningful results.  This is either a local thing ("My Uncle Jim says..."), a completely fabricated story to inspire ridiculous high school level research (of course it doesn't work, how the heck would it?), or an internet rumor that the researcher bought into enough to test.  Luckily SciShow did some super, super, easy, basic, introductory writing level research to find this out instead of just joining one of the many resurgences of this stupid myth.  Oh, wait...

I really don't understand how you can talk about this so casually. Imagine if people were doing this with some other kind of animal that more people find cuter, like squirrels. If you were catching squirrels with a hook that would get lodged in their throat, or would come out through their cheek, and then you would have to pull it out, ripping their flesh of their esophagus or the inside of their mouth, occasionally leading to them bleeding out, dying, after suffering for a while... My late husband used to do catch and release fishing. He only had one that we know of that died, apparently of shock, as he was pulling the hook out. To his credit, he did feel bad about that, but it didn't stop him from doing this. Fish are not like prizes, using a claw to pick a stuffed animal out of a machine. These are animals like us, fully enervated for pain. We can enjoy sitting by the water without having to hurt any other animal.

I have a theory. In humans, if you are exposed to an environment high in CO2 but normal in O2, you will feel out of breath easily. If there is low CO2 and low O2 you feel nothing wrong and pass out and maybe die. This is what happens when people enter a nitrogen environment and in the free diving shallow drowning phenomenon. It would appear that the fish have the same Rube Goldberg sense of how much oxygen is available vs needed as we do, likely because we inherited it from the fish.

It was new to me, so the first  chance I got, I asked an old man that I knew why would anyone pour soda on a fish.  He told me that was something everyone told their grand kids when they went fishing.  A fish would be caught that was bleeding a little, and the kids would be concerned for the fish, so the grand parents would make a big show of pouring a soda on it to "heal" it's gills and it would be fine.  Calmed the fears of the child for the fish, and grand dad could keep fishing with little to no more fuss.
I wonder if a styptic pencils would work on fish. It's designed to stop bleeding. It works on humans I wonder if scientists and biologists ever thought to see if it would work on fish.

Ah catch-and-release fishing so kind toward the fish... Imagine if a shark came up to a beach, bit a person in the leg, teath tearing the muscle and ligaments, then dragged the person down under the water. After this the shark then keeps the person under water for 30 seconds or so, and then release the bite after throwing the person above the waves.

If you think what the shark did would be considered to "just be having some fun", and there would be no consequences for the shark in that case, I don't think I understand you. And this is why in reverse I also don't buy how catch-and-release fishing is supposed to be kind to the fish, it's not. You're essentially torturing a fish for your own enjoyment.
